title: 108_hr3966
content: The Act may be cited as the "ROTC and Military Recruiter Equal Access to Campus Act of 2004". The ROTC program is a common path for undergraduates to become military officers, promoting diversity in leadership. It also benefits students by raising awareness of the military presence on college campuses. Land-grant colleges received land on the condition of offering military programs. The ROTC program is a common path for undergraduates to become military officers, promoting diversity in leadership. Colleges and universities are required to offer military instruction as part of their curriculum, contributing to the Nation's readiness. If any institution discriminates against ROTC programs or military recruiters, they may lose Federal taxpayer support. The Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Energy rely on well-educated military leadership to protect the US. Laws should be updated to prevent discrimination against ROTC and military recruiters on college campuses. SEC. 3. CERTIFICATION OF COMPLIANCE WITH ROTC ACCESS PROVISIONS. Section 983 of title 10, United States Code, is amended to require the Secretary of Defense to request certification from institutions of higher education with ROTC programs to ensure compliance with access provisions. The institution must allow military departments to maintain Senior Officer Training Corps units on campus. If a department chooses not to have a Senior Reserve Officer Training Corps unit, students can enroll in another institution's program. Certification must be provided by the institution's president to the Secretary of Defense. The institution must allow military departments to maintain Senior Officer Training Corps units on campus. Certification must be provided by the institution's president to the Secretary of Defense within 90 days. If the certification does not comply with the requirements, the Secretary will make a determination regarding the institution's policy or practice. SEC. 4 amends section 983 of title 10, United States Code to ensure equal access for military recruiters on campuses. SEC. 5 prohibits funding for post-secondary schools that restrict ROTC access or military recruiting. The amendment to section 983 of title 10, United States Code expands the covered funds to include the Department of Homeland Security, National Nuclear Security Administration, and Department of Transportation. The amendment expands covered funds to include the Department of Homeland Security, National Nuclear Security Administration, Department of Transportation, and Central Intelligence Agency. Amendments are made to subsections (b) and (e) of the section. SEC. 6. EXCLUSION OF AMOUNTS TO COVER INDIVIDUAL PAYMENTS. The text chunk discusses amendments to section 983 of title 10, United States Code, regarding the use of Federal funding for student financial assistance in institutions of higher education. It also includes conforming amendments and a repeal of a codified provision from the Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2000. The Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2000 (Public Law 106-79; 10 U.S.C. 983 note) is repealed. The amendments made by this Act will apply to funds appropriated for fiscal year 2005 and beyond.
